awd_titl_txt: The In/authentic Experiences of Black Engineers
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years there has been increasing scrutiny on diversity in the computer and information technology industry. Data on demographics portray an industry that lacks diversity. Even when engineers from underrepresented groups are hired by these companies, they tend to leave. Among people of color 40% of the men and 36% of the women leave due to unfair treatment. The economic cost of this issue is enormous. The cost to replace these workers is over $16 billion annually. Lack of diversity also results in lost productivity and innovation. Improving the diversity of the technology industry workforce requires a welcoming and inclusive workplace. In this project we are seeking to understand the experiences of Black engineers. The narratives developed from interviews with these workers are being used to illustrate the unique problems faced by Black engineers. Through conversations with industry leaders we are identifying approaches to make the workplace more welcoming to all.

This study involves interviews with 40 engineers in the technology industry. The goal of these interviews is to understand workplace climate. Interviews focus on the experiences they have had with their co-workers, supervisors, and customers. The data are being analyzed using narrative analysis, through the lens of three frameworks: Faulkner's in/authenticity, Helms and Piper's pairing of racial identity theory and vocational psychology, and Kendi's history of racist ideas. The result is individual narrative case studies for each person. Cross-case comparison identifies commonalities and differences in workplace culture, impact of social identity, and perceptions of inclusivity. Through conference sessions, we are creating a community of researchers focused on diversity and inclusion in the engineering workplace. Additionally, we are sharing findings and implications directly with industry leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In recent years there has been increasing scrutiny on diversity in the computer and information technology industry. Data on demographics portray an industry that lacks diversity. Even when engineers from underrepresented groups are hired by these companies, they tend to leave. Among people of color 40% of the men and 36% of the women leave due to unfair treatment. The economic cost of this issue is enormous. The cost to replace these workers is over $16 billion annually. Lack of diversity also results in lost productivity and innovation. Improving the diversity of the technology industry workforce requires a welcoming and inclusive workplace. In this project we sought to understand the experiences of Black engineers. The narratives developed from interviews with these workers illustrated the unique problems faced by Black engineers.


This study involved interviews with 24 engineers in the technology industry. The goal of these interviews was to understand workplace climate. Interviews focused on the experiences they had with their co-workers, supervisors, and customers. We saw that White and Black engineers had very different experiences in their workplaces. White engineers tended to merge their work and personal lives, resulting in a work experience we described as “authentic.” For example, coworkers were their friends, and they saw work as an extension of their personal lives. They acknowledged bias could occur, but said they had never observed it themselves. White men said they were expected to work long hours to succeed, while White women paid more attention to work-life balance. Overall, White engineers reported the workplace as an extension of their authentic selves.


In contrast, Black engineers reported that their personal and workplace lives were separate. They often acted differently in those settings in order to conform to “professional” expectations. Black engineers felt the need to control their emotions in ways their White colleagues didn’t. They also noted differences in advancement opportunities or financial rewards between White and Black engineers despite equal (or better) performance. We also heard several stories of specific instances of bias. One Black male like to listen to rap music while he worked, and he bought a set of high-end headphones so the music would not disturb others. Nevertheless, he was reported to management, even though his White colleague played games on his phone all day and was not reported. We also heard a story from a Black engineer who was promised a raise if he took over a project and got it completed on time. He completed the project, but when the time came for the raise he was told there was no money in the budget for it. We also heard stories of explicit racism.


Our results show that, despite popular claims of colorblindness and meritocracy in the workplace, racial bias still exists. This bias goes beyond individual behavior to encompass company policies and structures. These forms of bias exist despite any individual’s efforts to overcome them. Combatting bias requires that we explicitly identify and name these practices as the first step towards their removal.
